article.title: Biocontrol in built environments to reduce pathogen exposure and infection risk
funding: NSF ENG-EPSRC EFRI ELiS: Developing probiotic interventions to reduce the emergence and persistence of pathogens in built environments (UCSD 2223669)
NASA ROSBIO: Quantifying selection for pathogenicity and antibiotic resistance in bacteria and fungi on the ISS—a Microbial Tracking Study (80NSSC19K1604)
article.abstract: The microbiome of the built environment comprises bacterial, archaeal, fungal, and viral communities associated with human-made structures. Even though most of these microbes are benign, antibiotic-resistant pathogens can colonize and emerge indoors, creating infection risk through surface transmission or inhalation.

sections.introduction: Cleaning and disinfection practices in homes and hospitals to combat bacteria, fungi, and viruses have a long history. Ancient civilizations used various disinfection methods to remove “pestilence,” from the rudimentary practices of boiling and sunlight exposure to the use of natural substances like vinegar and sulphur [1]. However, it was not until the 19th century that the age of modern infection control began to take shape with targeted cleaning practices.

article.insights_summary: This review covers our current understanding of microbial ecology of the built environment and proposes strategies to translate that knowledge into effective biocontrol of antibiotic-resistant pathogens.
